Ce3+-incorporated HZSM-5 as efficient catalysts with rich-strong Brønsted acid sites for cyclohexene hydration Hefang Wang Writing – review & editing Visualization Supervision Methodology Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ 1 Shijiao Hao Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Project administration Methodology Investigation Data curation Conceptualization 1 Hui Jiang Writing – review & editing Xiaofei Ma Data curation Hashim Khan Data curation Jingwei Liu Data curation Weiqian Qi Data curation School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Hefang Wang and Shijiao Hao contributed equally to this work. A series of Ce3+ incorporated HZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method for cyclohexene hydration. XRD, Vacuum-IR, XPS, and 29Si NMR confirmed the successful incorporation of Ce3+ into the HZSM-5. NH3-TPD and Py-IR analyses revealed that Ce-HZSM-5 catalyst significantly increased strong Brønsted acid density compared to HZSM-5. Further, the strong Brønsted/Lewis acid ratio of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 is 4-fold higher than that of HZSM-5 (9.2 vs 2.3). As a result, the catalyst exhibited excellent activity with 12.7 % conversion of cyclohexene and 99.9 % selectivity to cyclohexanol and maintained high catalytic performance after five cycles. In situ FTIR was used to investigate the cyclohexene hydration reaction mechanism. The results showed that Ce3+ interacts with Si–OH to form a new strong Bronsted acid site (Si–OH–Ce). This site can effectively promote the activation of cyclohexene and significantly enhance the catalytic hydration performance. Graphical Abstract Keywords HZSM-5 Strong Brønsted acid sites Cyclohexene hydration Cyclohexanol Data Availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Cyclohexanol is used for the production of cyclohexanone and also used as raw materials for plasticizers, surfactants and detergent [1–3]. Generally, cyclohexanol is synthesized by three main routes: phenol hydrogenation, cyclohexane oxidation and cyclohexene hydration [4–7]. Phenol hydrogenation method is the earliest production process used for the synthesis of cyclohexanol. But the method was gradually eliminated due to high energy consumption and production costs caused by high hydrogen consumption [8]. Cyclohexane oxidation method is current commonly used for production of cyclohexanol. However, the method has drawbacks such as high corrosion of equipment, explosive, high energy consumption and low selectivity to cyclohexanol [9]. Compared with the above two methods, the cyclohexene hydration method for the production of cyclohexanol is attractive due to its low costs, energy efficiency, safe operation, and high selectivity to cyclohexanol [10,11]. Cyclohexene hydration proceeds as follows: (1) carbonium ions are formed by interaction between Brønsted acid and CC, which is the rate-determining step; (2) carbonium ion reacts with water to produce protonated alcohol; (3) protonated alcohol deprotonates to form cyclohexanol [12,13]. The first step as the rate-determining step in the cyclohexene hydration reaction, thus the Brønsted acid strength and density of the catalyst are important factors for achieving high cyclohexanol yields. The high Brønsted acid strength can effectively promote the protonation of cyclohexene molecules to form carbonium ion intermediates, thus accelerating the reaction process. While the Brønsted acid density directly determines the number of active sites and has a significant effect on the reaction rate and catalyst activity. Sulfuric acid was used as a homogeneous catalyst for this reaction, but it has disadvantage of strong corrosion for equipment and difficulty in separating the catalyst after the reaction [14]. Therefore, the development of heterogeneous catalysts is crucial for this reaction. Ion-exchange resins were used as heterogeneous catalysts for cyclohexene hydration, which are unsuitable for industrial scale-up because of poor thermal stability [13,15]. HZSM-5 zeolites were widely used as heterogeneous catalysts for cyclohexene hydration due to their unique advantages such as excellent shape selectivity, adjustable acid strength, high thermal stability and easy separation after reaction [12,16–18]. However, the limited Brønsted acid sites restrict its further application. Currently, researchers mainly enhance the Brønsted acid sites of HZSM-5 by acid treatment, alkali treatment or introduction of heteroatoms [19–21]. Wang et al. treated HZSM-5 using different concentrations of NaOH solution and found that low concentration of NaOH solution could significantly increase the content of strong and weak acid sites of HZSM-5 zeolite, thus increasing the conversion of cyclohexene [19]. Meng et al. modified HZSM-5 with Na2CO3 solution and used it for cyclohexene hydration reaction [21]. It was shown that the strong acid density (350 µmol/g) of HZSM-5 treated with 0.5 M Na2CO3 solution increased by 20 µmol/g compared to HZSM-5 (330 µmol/g). As a result, the conversion of cyclohexene increased from 10 % to 13 %. Tian et al. treated HZSM-5 with acid to expose more acidic sites, which effectively improved the efficiency of the cyclohexene hydration reaction [20]. However, these strategies often lead to an increase in post-processing time and cost, as well as damage to the zeolite structure, resulting in reduced stability. Introducing heteroatoms (Ga3+, B3+, Fe3+) into the HZSM-5 to regulate the density of Brønsted acid can overcome the above shortcoming and has been concerned increasingly by scientists [17,22,23]. Jin et al. prepared a series of Ga-HZSM-5 zeolite with hydrothermal method [17]. Compared with Ga0-HZSM-5, the Brønsted acid density of Ga3-HZSM-5 increased from 0.4 mmol/g to 0.5 mmol/g, and the conversion of cyclohexene increased from 8.6 % to 10.1 %. Yang et al. regulated Brønsted acid density by incorporated B3+ into HZSM-5 [22]. The results showed that the introduction of B3+ in HZSM-5 affects the distribution of Al in the framework by forming Si–OH–B, increased the weak Brønsted acid sites. Hence, the selected metal and its impact on the HZSM-5 framework are critical for improving the density and type of Brønsted acid. Herein, we prepared a series of Ce3+ incorporated HZSM-5 by wet impregnation method, and attempted to adjust the strong Brønsted acid density of HZSM-5 by changing the Ce3+ content. BET and SEM were used to detect the textural properties and morphology. The interaction between Ce species and HZSM-5 was explored by XRD, Vacuum-IR, H2-TPR, 29Si NMR and XPS. Acidity was investigated by NH3-TPD and Py-IR. In addition, the catalytic performance of Ce-HZSM-5 catalyst was evaluated using cyclohexene hydration as a probe reaction. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3= 46) zeolites were purchased from Nankai University Catalysis Co., Ltd. Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce (NO3)3‧6H2O, AR) was supplied by Aldrich. Before reaction, all catalysts were dried at 200 ℃ for 4 h. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Ce-HZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method. Typically, a calculated amount of Ce (NO3)3‧6 H2O was dissolved into 5.0 g of deionized water. Subsequently, 5.0 g of HZSM-5 was added to above solution. After stewing for 12 h, the obtained sample was dried at 100 ℃ for 12 h and calcinated at 550 ℃ for 6 h in air flow with 3 ℃/min. These catalysts were denoted as xCe-HZSM-5, where x was the calculated mass percentage of Ce in HZSM-5. For comparison, 3.0Ce/HZSM-5 catalyst was prepared by physical grinding method. Ce (NO3)3‧6 H2O was mixed with HZSM-5 and milled for 1 h, then calcinated at 550 ℃ for 6 h with 3 ℃/min, which was denoted as 3.0Ce/HZSM-5. 2.3 Catalytic tests The schematic diagram of the cyclohexene hydration reaction is shown in Fig. 1. In a typical cyclohexene hydration process, 0.8 g catalyst was added to 8.0 g of deionized water and 1.6 g of cyclohexene in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was charged 3–4 times with N2 to completely remove the air and then kept at 0.6 MPa. Subsequently, the reaction was carried out at 125 ℃ for 3 h. After reaction, the catalysts were collected by centrifugation, and liquid phase was extracted using 15 mL ethyl acetate for 3 times. The collected organic phase was determined by Thermo Trace DSQ GC-MS equipment. The reaction products were detected by a gas chromatograph (SP-3420A) with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a KB-1 column (30 m × 0.3 mm × 0.5 μm). The used catalyst was centrifuged and washed with ethanol for the next cycle. The conversion of cyclohexene and selectivity to products were calculated as following: Conversion ( % ) = n 0 Cyclohexene − n ( Cyclohexene ) n ( Cyclohexene ) × 100 % S electivity ( % ) = n i ∑ i = 1 n n i × 100 % Where n0 (Cyclohexene) is the initial molar quantity of cyclohexene, n (Cyclohexene) stands for final molar quantity of cyclohexene, ni stands for molar quantity of product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties and morphology The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of HZSM-5 and xCe-HZSM-5 zeolites are shown in Fig. 2. According to IUPAC classification, all N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts show typical type I isotherms, which indicated the existence of micropores [24]. Table 1 lists the textural properties of HZSM-5 and xCe-HZSM-5 zeolites. The specific surface area (SSA) gradually decreases with the increase of Ce content [25]. The SSA of the Ce-HZSM-5 (364.3 m2/g) catalyst showed a slight decrease compared to the parent HZSM-5 (392.0 m2/g). In contrast, the 3Ce/HZSM-5 catalyst prepared via physical grinding exhibited a significant reduction in SSA (336.8 m2/g). This differential behavior is mainly attributed to Ce species incorporate into the framework of HZSM-5 for 3.0Ce-HZSM-5, while mechanical treatment during milling leads to particle aggregation in 3.0Ce/HZSM-5. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 catalyst (Figure S1(a)) revealed a well-defined hexagonal prismatic crystal morphology with an average particle size of approximately 2 μm. EDS mapping analysis further confirmed the homogeneous distribution of Si, O, Al, and Ce elements (Figure S1 (b)). 3.2 Ce3+ incorporated HZSM-5 Fig. 3(a) shows the XRD patterns of all catalysts. The characteristic diffraction peaks of HZSM-5 zeolites (2θ = 7.9 °, 8.9 °, 23.0 °, 23.9 °, 24.4 °,29.2 ° and 29.9 °) are detected in the XRD patterns of all catalysts [26,27]. There are no related peaks of CeO2 are observed at 28.5 °, 33.1 ° and 47.5 ° (PDF#78–0694) in low Ce content, indicating that Ce species are highly dispersed in HZSM-5. However, characteristic CeO2 diffraction peaks appeared in the XRD patterns of 7Ce-HZSM-5, suggesting that excessive Ce loading resulted in the generation of large amounts of CeO2. The amplification peaks at 22.0–25.0 ° are shown in Fig. 3(b). It is shown that the diffraction peaks of xCe-HZSM-5 shift toward a low diffraction angle as the content of Ce increases. When the amount of Ce reaches 3 %, the diffraction peak shifts by 0.06 °,while no shifts occur for the diffraction peaks of 3.0Ce/HZSM-5 by the physical grinding method. This phenomenon may be caused by changes in the unit cell. Calculating the unit cell parameters found that the cell volume gradually rises with an increase in Ce content (Table 1, list 5). This is due to the lower lengths of Si–O and Al–O bonds (0.16 nm and 0.18 nm, respectively) compared to Ce–O bonds (0.24 nm), which cause lattice expansion [28]. These results suggest that Ce is incorporated into the framework of HZSM-5 zeolites for Ce-HZSM-5. The framework structure of all catalysts was analyzed using Vacuum-IR (Fig. 3(c)). Absorption bands at around 1096 cm–1 can be observed in HZSM-5 and xCe-HZSM-5 due to the asymmetric stretching of T–O–T [29]. As the increase of Ce content, the band gradually broadens and shifts towards a low wavenumber, which is due to the bond length of Ce–O is longer than that of the Al–O, resulting in a decrease in vibration frequency [28,29]. Furthermore, the observed band broadening suggests enhanced lattice distortion or localized structural disorder induced by Ce incorporation, confirming the successful integration of Ce species into the HZSM-5 framework and its consequential modification of the T–O–T bonding environment. Moreover, H2-TPR further demonstrates the incorporation of Ce species into the HZSM-5 framework for the Ce-HZSM-5 catalysts. The reduction peak around 500 ℃ in the H2-TPR profiles (Fig. 3(d)) was assigned to the reduction of CeOx species [30]. Notably, the significantly higher H₂ consumption observed for 3.0Ce/HZSM-5 compared to 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 demonstrates that 3.0Ce/HZSM-5 has a higher CeOx content while the Ce incorporate into the framework of HZSM-5 for 3.0Ce-HZSM-5. The results are consistent with the results of XRD and Vacuum-IR. To investigate the structural environment of Ce species within the HZSM-5 framework, Vacuum-IR was employed to characterize the hydroxyl group distribution. All samples were heat-treated under vacuum at 350 °C for 3 h and then IR spectra were collected. The OH stretching bands in the 3500–3700 cm⁻¹ region were analyzed to probe the interaction between Ce species and framework hydroxyls. The bands at 3745 cm−1 are OH vibration of terminal Si–OH group, while bridging OH groups (Si–OH–M) is associated with the bands at 3616 cm−1, which is usually related to Brønsted acid sites [31]. As shown in Figure S2, a systematic attenuation of the terminal Si–OH stretching vibration band (3745 cm⁻¹) occurs with the increase in cerium content from 0 % to 3 %, whereas the bridging hydroxyl (Si–OH–M) absorption at 3610 cm⁻¹ showed the inverse trend. This spectral evolution suggests an interaction between Ce species and terminal Si–OH. When the Ce content continues to increase up to 7 %, the Si–OH–M absorption band shows a decreasing trend, which is due to its coverage by excess CeO2 species. The effect of Ce introduction on the coordination states and chemical shifts of silicon atoms in HZSM–5 was further investigated using 29Si MAS NMR ( Fig. 4(a)). The signals in the 29Si MAS NMR spectra are divided into four regions by Gaussian convolution. In general, the peaks with the chemical shifts around –100 ppm and –105 ppm correspond to Q2 (Si 2 M) and Q3 (Si 1 M), respectively, while the peaks with chemical shifts of –112 and –116 ppm correspond to Q4 (Si 0 M) [25,32]. Compared with those of HZSM-5, the peaks of Q2 and Q3 of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 show a blue shift, which move from –100.5 to –103.8 ppm and –105.9 to –107.5 ppm, respectively, suggesting that the incorporation of Ce affects the chemical environments of Si (2 M) and Si (1 M). However, the Q4 peak remains unchanged, indicating that the incorporation of Ce has no influence on the chemical environment of Si (0 M) [25]. The relative value of Q4 (Si 0 M), Q3 (Si 1 M) and Q2 (Si 2 M) peak areas of HZSM-5 and 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 are listed in Table 2. With the increase of Ce incorporation, the peak area of Q2 (Si 2 M) significantly increases and the peak area of Q3 (Si 1 M) decreases slightly. This proves that Ce incorporate the framework of HZSM-5 by combining with the defects or terminal Si–OH bonds to form a new Si–OH–Ce bond. XPS analysis were used to further explore the interactions of Ce species with HZSM-5 and the presence of valence state. Fig. 4(b-c) shows the O1s and Si 2p XPS spectra of HZSM-5 and 3.0Ce-HZSM-5. The O1s peaks at 532.9 eV and 531.2 eV are attributed to oxygen in the zeolite framework and surface hydroxyl, respectively [33–35]. The corresponding increase in binding energy with decreasing electronegativity of adjacent atoms has been reported [36]. When cerium (Ce) species are introduced into HZSM-5, the peak at O 1 s (533.9 eV) shifts towards higher binding energy. This is due to the fact that cerium is of lower electronegativity than aluminum and silicon, resulting in an increase in the binding energy [37]. The Si 2p peaks at 102.7 eV and the Al 2p peaks at 74.8 eV are assigned to the Si–O and Al–O, respectively [34]. A new shoulder peak related to Si–O bonds occurred at Si 2p (104.3 eV) of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5, which is attributed to the shift of the Si 2p peak towards higher energies as the oxygen content increased [38]. However, the Al 2p binding energy of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 remained constant (Figure S3). These results further confirm that Ce is incorporated into the framework of HZSM-5 and formed Si–OH–Ce bonds. As shown in Fig. 4(d), the peaks with binding energies at 881.1 eV, 885 eV, 899.5 eV and 903.4 eV are assigned to Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2 of Ce3+ species, respectively. The peaks with binding energies of 882.8 eV, 889.4 eV, 898.7 eV, 901.2 eV, 907.5 eV and 917.1 eV are attributed to Ce4+ species [39,40]. The 3d5/2 photoemissions peaks are denoted as v, and the 3d3/2 photoemissions peaks are denoted as u. The relative content of Ce3+ and Ce4+ with different chemical valence states on catalyst surface is semi-quantified based on the following equation. c ( Ce 3 + ) = A v 0 + A v + A v ’ + A v ’ ’ + A v ’ ’ ’ A u 0 + A u + A u ’ + A u ’ ’ + A u ’ ’ ’ + A v 0 + A v + A v ’ + A v ’ ’ + A v ’ ’ ’ c ( Ce 4 + ) = A u 0 + A u + A u ’ + A u ’ ’ + A u ’ ’ ’ A u 0 + A u + A u ’ + A u ’ ’ + A u ’ ’ ’ + A v 0 + A v + A v ’ + A v ’ ’ + A v ’ ’ ’ As shown in Table 3, the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio of the 3.0Ce/HZSM-5 catalyst was 0.2, which was attributed to the fact that most of the non-framework CeOx existed in the form of CeO2, and only a few Ce3+ existed in the form of Ce2O3. However, the Ce3+/Ce4+ of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 increased to 0.7 compared to 3.0/Ce-HZSM-5, suggesting that the Ce species in the HZSM-5 framework are in the form of Ce3+. 3.3 Acid properties The acidity of xCe-HZSM-5 and 3.0Ce/HZSM-5 samples is measured by NH3-TPD. As shown in Fig. 5, the profiles of all samples are deconvoluted into three-Gaussian components with center temperatures of 250, 320 and 450 ℃, which correspond to ammonia desorption from the weak, moderate and strong acid sites, respectively [41,42]. Notably, the moderate and strong acid peaks for xCe-HZSM-5 shifted to higher temperature compared to HZSM-5, while the peak of weak acid slightly shifts, indicating that the introduction of framework-Ce3+ (Si–OH–Ce) increases the strength of the strong acid sites. Table 4 lists the distribution of acid density. Compared with the total acid density (927.2 µmol·g–1) and strong acid density (403.8 µmol·g–1) of HZSM-5, the total acid (1079.8 µmol·g–1) and strong acid density (500.6 µmol·g–1) of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 increased by 152.6 µmol·g–1 and 96.8 µmol·g–1. However, the weak and moderate acid densities show no significant change. This indicates the incorporation of Ce3+ mainly increases the density of strong acid. Because the incorporation of Ce3+ into the framework of HZSM-5 generates additional Brønsted acid sites through the formation of Si–OH–Ce bridging hydroxyl groups. Further addition of Ce to 7.0 % does not result in a continuous increase in total and strong acid density, due to the framework-Ce3+ content having already reached its maximum. Compared to the 3.0Ce-HZSM-5, the physically mixed 3.0Ce/HZSM-5 catalyst exhibited a substantial reduction in total acid density (700.0 μmol·g⁻¹) and strong acid density (326.9 μmol·g⁻¹), primarily attributed to the coverage of acidic sites by CeOx, which is consistent with XPS results. To further investigate the effect of Ce incorporation on the acid properties of catalyst, the Py-IR of HZSM-5 and 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 are compared ( Fig. 6). The band at 100 °C is due to the physical absorption of pyridine. The desorption of pyridine at 200 ℃ and 350 ℃ corresponds to the total acid and strong acid densities, respectively [43–45]. All catalysts display typical bands of adsorbed pyridine at around 1540 cm–1 (Brønsted acid sites, labeled as B), 1490 cm–1 (both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites), and 1446 cm–1 (Lewis acid sites, labeled as L) [41,46–49]. The densities of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites for HZSM-5 and 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 catalysts were calculated from the extinction coefficients of the different acid sites. The extinction coefficients of Brønsted acid (1.88) and Lewis acid (1.42) sites were obtained from previously reported literature [50]. As shown in Table 5, compared to the total (46.9 µmol g−1) and the strong (23.3 µmol g−1) Brønsted acid density of HZSM-5, the total (205.3 µmol g−1) and the strong (136.2 µmol g−1) Brønsted acid density of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 increased by 158.4 µmol g−1 and 112.9 µmol g−1. In addition, the B/L ratio of strong acid rises from 2.3 to 9.2, indicating that the formation of new Si–OH–Ce bonds can mainly remarkably increase the strong Brønsted acid density of HZSM-5. This result is consistent with the high-temperature desorption of NH3 by NH3-TPD. Therefore, as the Scheme 1, Ce species exist as Ce3+ and is connected to the Si–OH bonds in HZSM-5 to generate new strong Brønsted acid sites were proposed, which remarkably increase the density of strong Brønsted acid. 3.4 Catalytic performance The cyclohexene hydration reaction was controlled by Brønsted acid and was therefore used as a probe reaction to assess the catalytic properties of Ce-HZSM-5 zeolites (Figure S4) [13]. The conversion of cyclohexene and selectivity to cyclohexanol of HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3=46) catalyst incorporated with different Ce content were shown in Fig. 7(a). Similar selectivity to cyclohexanol (about 99.9 %) was obtained over all catalysts. In addition, compared with that of HZSM-5, all xCe-HZSM-5 had high yield of cyclohexanol. The conversion of cyclohexene increased from 9.9 % to 12.7 % when the Ce content was increased from 0 % to 3.0 %. According to the results of Vacuum-IR, XPS, 29Si NMR and Py-IR, more additional Si–OH–Ce bonds are generated by the interaction between Ce species and Si–OH of HZSM-5, which significantly increases the strong Brønsted acid density of HZSM-5 (active site). However, as Ce further increased from 3.0 % to 7.0 %, the yield of 5.0Ce-HZSM-5 and 7.0Ce-HZSM-5 decreased to 10.8 % and 10.5 % respectively, due to partial coverage of acidic sites of HZSM-5 by excessive CeOx. The above results were also confirmed by H2-TPR (Fig. 3(d)) and NH3-TPD (Fig. 5). The time effect of the catalytic activity of HZSM-5 and 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 at the same reaction conditions was also investigated. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the HZSM-5 catalyst obtained about 10 % cyclohexanol from cyclohexene within 3 h, while the 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 catalyst achieved the same cyclohexanol merely required 1.5 h. Besides, the catalytic activity of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 was higher than that of HZSM-5 at every reaction time. The results indicate that the 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 has remarkably greater catalytic activity than HZSM-5, attributed to the significant increase in the strong Brønsted acid density due to Ce incorporation into the framework of HZSM-5. In addition, the optimization of conditions for this reaction is shown in the Supporting information. For comparison, Table 6 summarizes the catalytic performance of different modified HZSM-5 catalysts in the cyclohexene hydration reaction. For the conversions of cyclohexene, the catalytic activity of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 (12.7 %) was much higher than that of Ga3-HZSM-5 (10.1 %), HCl-treated HZSM-5 (7.7 %), Microparticle ZSM-5 (9.6 %) and Hierarchical ZSM-5 (9.1 %). This is due to the abundant Brønsted acid sites and strong Brønsted acid density of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5. In addition, the cyclohexanol selectivity (99.9 %) of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 was higher than that of Na2CO3-treated HZSM-5 (99.3 %), NaOH-treated HZSM-5 (99.6 %), HZSM-5–1.5PEG (99.3 %), Microparticle ZSM-5 (96.8 %) and HCl-OTS-HZSM-5 (99.0 %). Therefore, an efficient 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 catalyst has been prepared, which not only has the excellent conversion of cyclohexene, but also has the nearly 100 % selectivity of cyclohexanol. 3.5 Mechanistic investigation The in situ FTIR technique was employed to further investigate the cyclohexene hydration reaction mechanism of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5. As shown in Fig. 8(a), stretching vibration peaks associated with cyclohexene was detected on the surface of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 catalysts at 0 min under the reaction conditions. The bands observed at 3030 cm–1 and 1643 cm–1 are attributed to CC and =C–H stretching vibrations [54–56]. The bands at 2933 cm–1 and 2852 cm–1 are ascribed to the stretching vibrations of the C–H bonds in the cyclic hydrocarbons [54,55]. The spectrum at 1452 cm–1 is due to the deformation vibrations from the bond with C–H [55]. With the introduction of H2O and prolongation of the reaction time (Fig. 8(a, b)), changes in the spectral bands associated with cyclohexanol were observed. (1) The band associated with the CC bond is shifted to a lower frequency, indicating that the CC bond of cyclohexene can be adsorbed on the HZSM-5 catalyst and interacts with the hydroxyl group to form a Π–OH complex [55]. (2) New infrared bands of 1282 cm–1, 1138 cm–1 and 1018 cm–1 associated with C–O stretching vibrations are gradually revealed, indicating the reaction of cyclohexene and water to produce cyclohexanol [4,57,58]. Moreover, the intensity of the stretching vibration peaks of the C-O bond showed an increasing and then decreasing trend, confirming that the cyclohexene hydration is a reversible reaction, which is consistent with previous reports in the literature [13].(3) The gradual increase in the intensity of the IR peaks at 2933 cm–1, 2852 cm–1 and 1452 cm–1 is attributed to the fact that the C–H stretching vibrational peaks and the deformation vibrational peaks of cyclohexanol occur at the same wavenumber. Notably, the intensity of the stretching vibration peaks associated with cyclohexene is much higher for the 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 catalyst than that of HZSM-5 (Fig. 8(b)), suggesting that 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 has more active sites, which is also consistent with the NH3-TPD and Py-IR results. In addition, the peaks associated with C-O bonding of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 have stronger extensional vibrational intensities. This is due to the fact that the Ce3+ of the 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 catalyst with can form a new Si–OH–Ce bond with the Si–OH bond, which accelerates the activation of the CC bond of cyclohexene, and thus increases the generation of cyclohexanol. This is also consistent with the experimental results. 3.6 Catalyst stability The recycling tests were conducted to evaluate the reusability of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 catalysts. After the reaction, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, washed with ethanol, dried, and reused for the next recycle. As shown in Fig. 9, the conversion of cyclohexene remained 11.2 % for 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 after five recycling runs, indicating good reusability. The reason for the slight decrease in catalyst activity after five cycles (labeled as R-3.0Ce-HZSM-5) was analyzed using XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption and NH3-TPD. Compared with those of fresh 3.0Ce-HZSM-5, no noticeable changes are observed in the XRD patterns and the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of R-3.0Ce-HZSM-5(( Fig. 10 (a, b)). However, the specific surface area and the micropore volume of R-3.0Ce-HZSM-5 were distinctly lower than those of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 (Fig. 10 (c) and Table S1), which is due to the deposition of organic carbon on the catalyst surface. Subsequently, NH3-TPD was performed to assess the acidity of R-3.0Ce-HZSM-5. All peaks of R-3.0Ce-HZSM-5 are shifted to a low temperature compared to those of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 (Fig. 10 (d)), indicating a decrease in the strength of weak, moderate and strong acids. Besides, the density of strong acid remarkably declines from 500.6 to 152.1 µmol g–1, and the density of total acid reduces from 1079.8 to 237.9 µmol g–1after five reaction cycle (Table S1). This may be due to the deposition of organic carbon covers some acidic sites. To confirm the hypothesis of the cause of catalyst deactivation, the catalyst from the last cycle was calcined at 550 ℃ for 6 h reused in the cyclohexene hydration reaction (labeled as 1※). The conversion of cyclohexene by catalyst 1※was recovered to 12.5 %. Therefore, the decrease in catalytic activity of Ce-HZSM-5 should be attributed to the deposition of organic carbon. 4 Conclusion A series of Ce3+ incorporated HZSM-5 with adjustable strong Brønsted acid densities were prepared by wet impregnation method. The textural properties and morphology of catalyst were tested by N2 adsorption-desorption and SEM. Various characterization methods such as XRD, Vacuum-IR, H2-TPR, 29Si NMR and XPS were used to confirm that Ce3+species were incorporated into HZSM-5 and were connected to Si–OH to form Si–OH–Ce. Combined with the NH3-TPD and Py-IR, the formation of Si–OH–Ce bonds create additional Brønsted acid sites, resulting in the increase in the total and strong Brønsted acid densities. In the cyclohexene hydration reaction, 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 exhibited excellent activity with a cyclohexene conversion of 12.7 % and cyclohexanol selectivity of 99.9 %. Furthermore, this catalyst also had a good reusability. CRediT authorship contribution statement Weiqian Qi: Data curation. Hui Jiang: Writing – review & editing. Xiaofei Ma: Data curation. coredata.dc:description: A series of Ce3+ incorporated HZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method for cyclohexene hydration. XRD, Vacuum-IR, XPS, and 29Si NMR confirmed the successful incorporation of Ce3+ into the HZSM-5. NH3-TPD and Py-IR analyses revealed that Ce-HZSM-5 catalyst significantly increased strong Brønsted acid density compared to HZSM-5. Further, the strong Brønsted/Lewis acid ratio of 3.0Ce-HZSM-5 is 4-fold higher than that of HZSM-5 (9.2 vs 2.3). As a result, the catalyst exhibited excellent activity with 12.7 % conversion of cyclohexene and 99.9 % selectivity to cyclohexanol and maintained high catalytic performance after five cycles. In situ FTIR was used to investigate the cyclohexene hydration reaction mechanism. The results showed that Ce3+ interacts with Si–OH to form a new strong Bronsted acid site (Si–OH–Ce). This site can effectively promote the activation of cyclohexene and significantly enhance the catalytic hydration performance.
coredata.dc:title: Ce3+-incorporated HZSM-5 as efficient catalysts with rich-strong Brønsted acid sites for cyclohexene hydration
